data.title: Price List of 1,932 Celebrities, Bands & Famous Entertainers
data.meta_description: Prices for musicians, Live DJs, comedians, TV Personalities, vegas acts, & bands.Taylor Swift is the highest paid entertainer at $3,000,000+. %
data.text:
Why does an agency never show its prices on the website?

Have you ever noticed booking agencies do not list pricing for the entertainers they represent? This is why we have created the most extensive list of entertainers with pricing on the internet.

YES, We know that the list isn’t 100% accurate. We understand that some of this data is from almost a decade ago. Regardless, the list is yours for reference. Use it as a resource when preparing an offer for the entertainer of your choice.

Disclaimers

Some of the sources we referenced are many years old and may have paid inflated or deflated pricing depending on their market and who was buying or selling the act

We do not directly represent any of the artists listed on the price sheet

Some of these prices reflect a flat deal structure

Got a new artist price?

Feel free to send it to us and we will update the list.

THIS LIST HAS OVER 1,900 ARTISTS & TOOK A DECADE TO CURATE

Why does it cost so much to hire a celebrity to perform at my event

The cost of having a celebrity, DJ, magician, band, or actor perform or appear at your event is subjective.

The talent agency knows that the client or venue wants to increase attendance or profit from selling tickets to their event. What they don’t know is how interested we are or how profitable the event will be.

This is why talent agencies require YOU to submit the initial offer. It is so they can gauge your interest, gather details, and leverage for the negotiation.

Most agents don’t want their time wasted, so getting all the event details outlined ahead of time is more efficient for everyone, including the artist.

Does The Price Change?

While we understand that these are only rough figures, the actual cost is negotiable and can be more dependent on other factors.

The price for each band will always go up or down depending on the timing of the market.

A booking agency bases its prices on perceived value and the venue’s desire to hire an act.

Example: We have seen two different properties in WA state pay two different prices in less than one year.

Just south of the Canadian border a casino paid $22,000 for a certain act (which is a $12,500 act anywhere else in the US) and in that same year, they were hired at a different casino for just $15,000 less than a 100 miles away.

What’s the bottom line? Always try to cross-reference pricing with other venues, talent buyers, and agents.

No matter what type of deal/offer you are pursuing, consulting with at least one other venue can only help.

It is important to remember that the artists will have an absolute bottom dollar amount that they are not willing to take less than.

The agent isn’t usually going to tell you that number, so if you don’t have an educated suggested starting point, you could get taken advantage of.
